<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 123, 637, 146]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 185]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 224, 165, 237]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 213, 424, 259]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[891, 278, 905, 292]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[731, 299, 905, 314]]<|/det|> February/March 2025 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 325, 395, 341]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 386, 391, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: List of formulae (MF19) <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 291, 450]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 451, 761, 466]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 565, 497]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 482, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 529, 867, 545]]<|/det|> - If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 482, 575]]<|/det|> - You should use a calculator where appropriate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 881, 591]]<|/det|> - You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 856, 620]]<|/det|> - Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 669, 214, 680]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 683, 388, 698]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 50 . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 714]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 449, 89]]<|/det|>
1 Jacob throws three coins at the same time. The first coin is biased so that the probability of obtaining a head when it is thrown is \(\frac{1}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 107, 827, 128]]<|/det|>
The second coin is biased so that the probability of obtaining a head when it is thrown is \(\frac{1}{4}\). The third coin is biased so that the probability of obtaining a head when it is thrown is \(\frac{1}{5}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 146, 556, 159]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) is the number of heads obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 174, 361, 194]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(\mathrm{P}(X=2)=\frac{3}{20}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 484, 532, 501]]<|/det|>
(b) Draw up the probability distribution table for \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
2 Last year, an online store sold a large number of computers. \(55 \%\) of the computers were made by company \(F\), 30\% were made by company \(G\) and \(15 \%\) were made by company \(H\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 802, 138]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 3 customers who each bought a computer from this store is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 151, 877, 168]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the probability that the 3 customers bought computers all made by different companies.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 429, 813, 446]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 12 customers who each bought a computer from this store is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 460, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the probability that fewer than 10 of these customers bought a computer made by company \(F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 824, 91]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 140 customers who each bought a computer from this store is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
(c) Use a suitable approximation to find the probability that more than 24 of these customers bought a computer made by company \(H\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|> 3 The lengths of 250 leaves of a certain type of plant are measured, correct to the nearest centimetre. The results are summarised in the table below. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[150, 119, 849, 173]]<|/det|>
Length (cm)
\(5-9\)
\(10-14\)
\(15-19\)
\(20-24\)
\(25-29\)
\(30-39\)
Frequency
18
28
60
72
48
24
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 201, 808, 218]]<|/det|> (a) On the grid below, draw a cumulative frequency graph to illustrate this information. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[258, 228, 741, 704]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 526, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) 38\% of these leaves are of length \(k \mathrm{~cm}\) or more.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 105, 474, 122]]<|/det|>
Use your graph to find an estimate for \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 259, 639, 276]]<|/det|>
(c) Calculate an estimate for the mean length of these 250 leaves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
4 Eddie has 16 toy cars, of which 8 are white, 5 are black and 3 are silver. He places all the cars in a bag and selects three of them at random, without replacement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 611, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the probability that all three cars are the same colour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the probability that, when the 3 cars are selected, at least one car is white and at least one car is black.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
5 The mass of peaches sold per day in a supermarket is normally distributed with mean 65.8 kg and standard deviation 9.6 kg ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
（a）Find the probability that the mass of peaches sold on any given day is between 56 kg and 75 kg ． ［3］

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[973, 231, 989, 382]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[973, 426, 989, 577]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
The mass of cherries sold per day in a supermarket is normally distributed with mean 72.4 kg and standard deviation \(\sigma \mathrm{kg}\). It is known that on \(10 \%\) of days less than 59.1 kg of cherries are sold.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 316, 138]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the value of \(\sigma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 490, 432, 508]]<|/det|>
The supermarket is open 7 days a week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 521, 921, 540]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the probability that, in a randomly chosen week, the first day on which less than 59.1 kg of cherries are sold is the fifth day of the week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 659, 921, 677]]<|/det|>
(d) Find the probability that, in a randomly chosen week, the first day on which less than 59.1 kg of cherries are sold is before the fifth day of the week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
6 Alissa has 10 different books from the series Squares and Circles. The books look similar except for their colour. There are 3 blue books, 2 red books, 2 yellow books, 1 orange book, 1 purple book and

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 228, 122]]<|/det|>
1 green book.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 908, 152]]<|/det|>
Alissa places the books in a row on her shelf. She is only interested in the arrangement of the colours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 686, 182]]<|/det|>
(a) How many different colour arrangements are there of the 10 books?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 445, 918, 462]]<|/det|>
(b) How many different colour arrangements are there of the 10 books in which the 3 blue books are together, but the 2 yellow books are not next to each other?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) How many different colour arrangements are there of the 10 books with exactly 4 books between the 2 yellow books?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 427, 793, 446]]<|/det|>
Alissa selects 4 books from her 10 different books from the series Squares and Circles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 459, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
(d) Find the number of different selections if the 4 books include at least 1 red book, at most 1 blue book and exactly 1 yellow book.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
